review_title: Fun place to be, until it's not.
pros: Awesome perks esp since they are under Accenture now.  Some colleagues are very nice and willing to help you out, especially the younger gen. Some teams are good to work with.
cons: Leads and managers gaslighting. Power imbalance, lack of empathy and heavy workload. Unrealistic deadlines and expectations.

review_title: Good overall speaking but lots of fussy minor uncomfortable areas  ( companies have it)
pros:
- environment, colleagues (most of it), superiors are good
- flexible work options (from home, client site, office, up to you)
- learns a lot (jumping into unfamiliar projects every time)
- used to have lots of entertainment at the office, people are infusion, fun, young and energetic
- pay / benefits are ok
cons:
- if you are not a sociable person, you fxxked (unless... you have a leader that fight/taught/and really lead you)
- if you are on bench for over 1 month or 2, you fxxked 
- sometimes, or most of the time, you will be assigned to projects that you are not good at, or even have no idea how to do it... you need to figure out by your own
- the promotion system is... you would never know.
- restructured twice in 2 years.... which I still not yet able to understand which team/pillar I am at.

review_title: A good career starting point, but awful in the long run
pros:
- Flexi time
- Sometimes pays out rendered overtime
- Top-notch HMO (Maxicare)
- Definitely a good starting point for Tech Careers
cons:
- Career experience will depend on the quality of the team that you'll be deployed into
- Career growth and opportunities quite scarce
- OTY's (Overtime Thank You) more often than not
- I encountered Tech Leads who took made credit-grabbing as a habit which resulted to him being promoted, while my colleagues and I received a measly 1% salary increase
- Being part of a high quality and great team is like a lottery, you need to be really lucky to be deployed into one

review_title: One of the worst place for Actuarial professionals. Join at your own risk, as the place is a big bait.
pros: None just big fake promises of management
cons:
Accenture is not a place to be an Actuarial professional as the company is not Actuarial friendly. 
The culture is driven by dirty politics as the managers would force you to work terribly long hours, pay less, provide no people or technical support (as they themselves are not-knowledgeable), torture their juniors and play dirty politics to save themselves from taking responsibility of their own failures while managing their team.
The attrition is extremely high, management is highly inconsistent with their promises and there is no respect for human as they make fake promises of mental health. 
The study policy is sub-standard as they don't have enough budget to support people to give exams and reach qualification. 
Accenture has anti-poaching agreements with different Companies which restricts people to move freely to other organizations.
Join the Accenture actuarial team, only if you want to learn dirty politics and take risk of playing with your own career. 
I would suggest aspiring people to take 10-20% less hike and join another Actuarial firm than joining Accenture, as one would end up compromising on their mental health for some money, which is not worth it.

pros:
- Accenture stands for inclusiveness.
- Graduate programs.
- Extra curricular engagement.
- Main HQ Leadership Communications (Julia Sweet, Scott Hahn).
- Nice offices.
- Excellent Corporate Services Staff.
- You can bench yourself if you have issues with your project.
cons:
- The project really will determine your time at Accenture. Bad line managers never get re-trained or told the hard truth. 
- Tantrums get you places.
- Base Pay is INCLUSIVE of Superannuation. This is NOT base pay and it deceives young employees when they get the offer email.
- Bonuses being told during interview process are fictitious
- HR issues get swept under the rug
- Promotions and bonuses are based on Managing Director of Projects discretion. If you don't have a champion in talent discussions you will not get promoted.
- People cry in the stair cases when they are overwhelmed. More check ins on staff needed.

review_title: Wasted Talent.  Self first culture. Fake HR.
job_title: Executive Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Pays well.
Great Research and Tools. 
Quality Online Videos to learn from (but all in your own time)
20% of the MD’s actually care about people.
60% of MD’s actually care about their clients.
Hires Great People who believe in Accenture
cons:
Actuality is nothing like the Employee Experience touted during Onboarding and Hiring. You are just a number.
HR can’t handle the truth.
20% Turnover of staff annually.
60% of staff are always looking to leave.
80% of MD only care about themselves.
Individuals set up to fail. Intense. Combative.
16 hours days expected but told charge only 8 hrs.
80% PowerPoint / 20% Add-Value. Pedantic.
Minimal support, mentoring or coaching. 
Prepared to let great people sit on the bench unused for 90 days. 
Treats new associates and new hires badly. No assignment pipeline.
Internal Assignment marketplace is a complete failure. Not used to actually assign staff. But a very nice and shiny system nevertheless.
The HR function believes their own hype. Won’t see / Can’t see that Accenture values are not valued. 
CHRO is too self-absorbed to hire from within because front line consultants know the truth. HR says the right things but reality is fake.

pros: The company works with exciting clients and has many ideas, that's the only positive thing I can say.
cons: The company and management don't care about their employees (only talking about the CDTS department). It's more important to submit deals to clients than the mental well-being of own employees. The department/company expects you to be ready to drop all your private plans (post working hours) to be able to submit to the last-minute deadline that tends always to happen. There is no such thing as work-life balance, as I can't count how many times I've had to cancel evening plans because a last-minute deadline pops up. Management expects you to be ready 24/7 to work on a client deal, and if you have plans drop them, and if you decide to stick with your private plans, you can forget about promotion. In short, A LOT of overtime and working all-nighters...

pros:
Quite good benefits - Sodexo card, cafeteria points and possibility to get bonuses (e.g. for relocation, yearly bonus if goals are met and more).
Nice colleagues and many employees so possibility to find friends
If you can play the game you can succeed, but it’s not for everyone.
cons:
In best case they are bad at communicating which leads to unnecessary misunderstandings and disappointments.
They are looking for too experienced people for entry level positions, a lot of positions are frankly customer support but they portray it as something else with a nicer title and requires years of experience.
It’s said it’s easy to move within the company and the staff has good possibilities to thrive and get higher levels/positions. But a lot of employees were waited months or years to get a promised promotion and even when they got the work for the new position and more responsibilities they did not “level up” or got the salary raise accordingly.
It’s high expectations for little reward.

job_title: Social Media Account Executive in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
- quick and efficient interview process 
- opportunity to work under the title of a social media giant 
- great employees that should be appreciate more
cons:
Where do I start:

- base salary is far lower than similar roles elsewhere 
- KPI’s had recently become unachievable due to situations beyond our control which accounted for a huge loss in high performing and tenured agents in recent months
- huge changes to the structure and dynamic of the programme
- zero flexibility offered when it comes to WFH or a hybrid model. They wish to return to office full time 
- large emphasis put on us (social media account execs) to increase productivity, however, there had been a lead volume issue for 6 months and nothing was ever resolved/explained. We tried our best with the resources we had and this was not recognised
- lack of praise and recognition. Tenured agents had taken on more than what was required for the role and it was never appreciated other than the odd ‘clap on the back’
- got the impression that our superiors were ‘under the thumb’ of the social media company and nothing was ever fought from our corner. Constant need to please the client without listening to those who should matter more
- progression opportunities may arise from time to time but the low salaries prevented anyone from ever applying, most people moved on from the role after 9/10 months


Overall, this role had a lot of potential but slowly I realised that there was better opportunities elsewhere.

review_title: Good name on a cv but more cons than pro
pros: In general, people are friendly and helpful. There are plenty of events and training opportunities. It’s also a great name to have on your cv, especially at the beginning of your career, as it will attract interest from a lot of other employers. The holiday package is decent and your extra hours are paid with extra holidays. The London office is pretty nice. There is a lot of emphasis on mental health and on inclusivity. Most project are very flexible and accommodating when it comes to WFH policy.
cons:
- If you don’t like the project you’re in, you might just have to stay and be stuck doing boring work for several months. 
- Some people have a tendency to micromanage, which is very frustrating. 
- Very slow promotion cycles, no adjustments to cost of living made for three years in a row and in general the benefits and pay is low. Some competitors pay the same entry level position twice as much.
- Except for holidays package, benefits aren’t great and those that are available are often “hidden”, as if the company didn’t really want employees to find out about them
- Workflow is very irregular and in general there is poor resource management and planning, so you might end up doing nothing for days and then having to work late for multiple weeks. This is especially true at the beginning, where a lot of new joiners spend weeks waiting to be assigned to a project and just wasting precious time. 
- There is also a lot of pressure to do “side desk” work alongside your required project work. This type of work is often just useless and takes time and energy away from you but without it your chances to get promoted are halved. 
- Travel to client site (although rare nowadays) can be very stressful, and depending on where you live in London, you might have to travel 2h to client and back everyday. (I had to do that pre-pandemic for 4 months and it was the most miserable experience)
- It’s a very big corpo environment and it really feels like it. You constantly feel like a number and it’s hard to find a project where you can actually see the impact of your work. I often struggled to feel valued and instead I frequently felt easily replaceable and disregarded.
- Not a great culture in general.

review_title: Decent Company with good work culture and rewards
pros:
Yearly Salary increase - You can get increase by inflation and if you are overachiever you can also get additional increase

Financial Bonuses - Received one few months after joining as "thank you for the last year work" which was funny. 

Basic corporate stuff - Caffeteria/money to spend on hobbies, Personal day off

Non crappy equipment - While not perfect, stuff I received was good and new. I had experience in companies before when they'd give us 6 year old notebook or notebooks that restarted by themselves

Fully paid PN. ETC...

I suppose this company can also be good for start and to get experience and is also not bad if you stay there longer.

So far I have good experience with the company overall although project experience is individual. Some can suck but some are fine but company as whole gives OK salaries compared to competition in country where I live. They also give yearly raises which doesn't happen that often in some other companies. They also supported us during lockdown, gave us additional budget to buy stuff for work etc. 
For people that are into "safe space" and "minorities" it's probably also good company.
cons:
Salary, while not bad for industry, is quite average.

Experience with work can vary from project to project. Some projects are good, some are terrible. (I personally got good project).

Peer rating basis:

review_title: You will learn a lot but it will take everything you have
pros: The experience I gained in my time at Accenture was invaluable and I am more confident and capable going into new positions now. Accenture also pays well so it makes for a good hop to increase your base pay.
cons: You will work your tail off. It will cost you all of your time and sanity. I sat it meetings for nearly 10 hours a day and didn't have any time for any real work. If I escalated that to my account leads, I would get some flimsy excuse about how it would get better after we did this or that... it never did. I woke up every day stressed out and worn out and my life and health were suffering for it. I could never relax or destress. The only way to be successful at Accenture is if you eat, sleep, and breath Accenture and work and do all kinds of Accenture specific initiatives in addition to everything else! There's a checklist you have to meet in order to get a promotion and everything in the organization is set up as a "one-size-fits all".

pros:
・very big company with many projects
This means that you do not need to care too much about the relationship with other people. Because if your boss is not a nice guy, if you boss give you power harassment, you can just request to change your project assign and go to other projects.
You can meet with many smart colleges in different industry and in different roles. This will help you broaden your skills.

・energetic colleges
Most Accenture people love work, especially those who graduated from university and joined Accenture directly.
Also they would like to challenge the new things, even if they have not done it before.

・Cooperative colleges(in some projects may be not)
cons:
・Accenture Japan is very Japanese, not international enough 
Actually, Accenture Japan is not an international environment, most of the employees are Japanese people. Even some of the Accenture Leadership people can not speak English, it is quite a big problem I think.

・Bad work-life balance for managers
Managers really have a long work time. Especially because the Japanese government regulated the work time for the staff, managers must cover the workload for staff. They really work for a long time every day.Maybe it is a good choice for those who really love working.

・too much involution
Such as when we are working at  client side, then we will decrease the lunch time, and if the client requests a meeting in the evening, we also need to answer it.

・facing client
Facing client is actually stressful. Because it will bring a strong stressful environment.And Accenture price is very high, so Accenture people need to offer more value than any other system integration company. And Accenture will also cut the members in the project to improve the profit.

pros: Easy work, your peers are typically around your age, supportive team, and non-hostile environment.
cons: The day to day work is actually quite easy, what makes it quick for many people to burn out is their slow processes and constant ad-hocs you need to do to correct other people's errors to make your data clean. The analyses required for this job are quite simple, so there's not much room for growth to gain additional transferrable skills, but its worth learning on your own to improve your own analyses. This role is not client facing, but you present to executives in your portfolio but depending on the project you are on you may not know what your client's work is, so explaining variances can be a shot in the dark.

review_title: Virtue signaling company who only cares about the bottom line
pros: The benefits are standard: pension, health care, etc, and nothing out of the ordinary in Dublin. Working from home but every company offers that now as well.
cons: Accenture employs over half a million people but the majority is in low paid countries such as India and the Philippines. This is the direction the company is going in, so if you are considering a role, keep in mind that it eventually could be offshored to places like India. Or, you could just be managing a team in delivery centre such as Bangalore. If that's what you want from your career then go for it but i'd rather work with people who are actually in the office. Irish people seem to be oblivious to the fact that they were once a delivery centre for American tech and medical companies. Now, as the cost of living has gone up, so too has the salaries and consequently the jobs are beginning to leave again to the next delivery centre location. The ridiculous fact is, Irish people are actually training these people in India, who will eventually take their jobs or other Irish people's. Of course, no one thinks about their own job in this way though. Everyone thinks that would never happen to them.

review_title: Great place to start and grow career
job_title: Data Management Senior Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Managers, Sr Managers really care about the growth of the people on their teams
Great place to make connections with people 'going places'
Work with the biggest global clients and their biggest hardest problems
Lots of opportunities to learn with free trainings, certifications, etc. even if it is not directly related to you work
If you get on a good project at a good client you will look forward to going to work every day
Pre-COVID (and hopefully post) if you like to travel, plenty of opportunities for that; but also if you want to stay local there are lots of good clients in Philadelphia area
cons:
Get lost in the 650,000+ employees; hard to consistently make good decisions about people when there are so many of them
The performance / rewards cycle is slow and can not react to market; a lot of good people leave
Can get pigeon holed if you stay in the same client / area of business for too long (move around; get lots of different experiences!)
Pay can stagnate compared to market
The luck involved (sometimes) of getting on a good project/client in the right role
